title: Doxycycline Hyclate Oral: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for doxycycline hyclate oral on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) is used to treat a wide variety of [bacterial infections](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/bacterial-and-viral-infections), including those that [cause acne](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/acne/acne-causes). This medication is also used to prevent [malaria](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/malaria). This medication is known as a [tetracycline](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-5919/tetracycline+oral/details) antibiotic. It works by stopping the growth of bacteria.This antibiotic treats only bacterial infections. It will not work for [viral infections](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/bacterial-and-viral-infections) (such as [common cold](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cold-or-flu-quiz), [flu](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cold-or-flu-quiz)). Using any antibiotic when it is not needed can cause it to not work for future infections. How to use doxycycline hyclate oral Read the Patient Information Leaflet if available from your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) before you start taking [doxycycline](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-14449/doxycycline+oral/details) and each time you get a refill. If you have any questions, ask your doctor or pharmacist. This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) is best taken by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth) on an empty [stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-stomach) (at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal) as directed by your doctor, usually 1 or 2 times daily. Take this medication with a full glass of water (8 ounces/240 milliliters) unless directed otherwise. If [stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/rm-quiz-surprising-stomach-facts) upset occurs, taking it with food or milk may help. However, doxycycline may not work as well if you take it with food or milk (or anything high in [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1575/calcium+oral/details) - more details below ), so ask your doctor or pharmacist if you may take it that way. Do not lie down for at least 10 minutes after taking this medication. Take this medication 2 to 3 hours before or after taking any products containing aluminum, [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/food-recipes/ss/slideshow-gourmet-calcium), iron, [magnesium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/supplement-guide-magnesium), zinc, or [bismuth](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-8061/bismuth+oral/details) didanosine solution, [quinapril](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-6254/quinapril+oral/details), [vitamins](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/lifestyle-guide-11/vitamin-expert)/ [minerals](https://www.webmd.com/food-recipes/vitamin-mineral-sources), dairy products (such as milk, yogurt), and [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/calcium-food-calculator/default.htm)-enriched juice. These products bind with doxycycline, preventing your body from fully absorbing the drug. When using to prevent [malaria](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/malaria), take this medication as directed by your doctor, usually once daily, starting 1 to 2 days before travel. Continue to take this medication daily while in the malarious area. Upon returning home, you should keep taking this medication for 4 more weeks. If you are unable to finish this course of doxycycline, contact your doctor. If you are using the liquid form of this medication, shake the bottle well before each dose. Carefully measure the dose using a special measuring device/spoon. Do not use a household spoon because you may not get the correct dose. The dosage is based on your medical condition and response to treatment. For children, the dosage may also be based on [weight](https://www.webmd.com/diet/tc/healthy-weight-what-is-a-healthy-weight). For the best effect, take this antibiotic at evenly spaced times. To help you remember, take this medication at the same time(s) every day. Continue to take this medication until the full prescribed amount is finished, even if symptoms disappear after a few days. Stopping the medication too early may allow bacteria to continue to grow, which may result in a return of the infection. Tell your doctor if your condition lasts or gets worse. Side Effects [Stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-stomach) upset, [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea), [nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), or [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting) may occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) promptly. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your doctor has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. Tell your doctor right away if you have any serious side effects, including: painful/difficult swallowing, signs of [kidney](https://www.webmd.com/kidney-stones/picture-of-the-kidneys) problems (such as change in the amount of urine). [Tetracycline](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-5919/tetracycline+oral/details) drugs such as [doxycycline](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-14449/doxycycline+oral/details) may rarely cause increased pressure around the [brain](www.webmd.com/brain/picture-of-the-brain-vue3) (intracranial hypertension-IH). The risk of this side effect is greater for women of childbearing age who are [overweight](https://www.webmd.com/diet/obesity/features/am-i-obese) or who have had IH in the past. If IH develops, it usually goes away after doxycycline is stopped; however, there is a chance of permanent [vision loss](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/coping-vision-loss) or blindness. Get medical help right away if you have: [headache](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/migraines-headaches-basics) that is severe or doesn't go away, nausea/vomiting doesn't stop, [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) changes (such as blurred/ [double vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/double-vision-diplopia-causes-symptoms-diagnosis-treatment), decreased vision, sudden blindness). This medication may rarely cause a severe intestinal condition due to a bacteria called C. difficile. This condition may occur during treatment or weeks to months after treatment has stopped. Tell your doctor right away if you develop: [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/diarrhea-10/slideshow-foods-to-avoid) that doesn't stop, abdominal or [stomach pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/abdominal-pain-causes-treatments)/cramping, [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood)/ [mucus](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/features/the-truth-about-mucus) in your stool. If you have these symptoms, do not use anti- [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/video/drossman-diarrhea-overview) or [opioid](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/narcotic-pain-medications) products because they may make symptoms worse. Use of this medication for prolonged or repeated periods may result in oral [thrush](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/what-is-thrush) or a new [vaginal yeast infection](https://www.webmd.com/women/understanding-vaginal-yeast-infection-basics). Contact your doctor if you notice white patches in your [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth), a change in [vaginal discharge](https://www.webmd.com/women/vaginal-discharge-whats-abnormal), or other new symptoms. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: fever that doesn't go away, new or node swelling](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/swollen-lymph-nodes-topic-overview), [dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics), [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist. In the US - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088 or at www.fda.gov/medwatch. In Canada - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to Health Canada at 1-866-234-2345. Precautions See also Side Effects section. Before taking [doxycycline](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-14449/doxycycline+oral/details), tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) if you are allergic to it; or to other tetracyclines (such as [minocycline](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/mono-8073-MINOCYCLINE+-+ORAL.aspx?drugid=7722&drugname=minocycline+oral)); or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients (such as sulfites, soy found in some brands), which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your pharmacist for more details. Before using this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), tell your doctor or pharmacist your medical history, especially of: trouble swallowing, [esophagus](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-esophagus) problems (such as [hiatal hernia](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/hiatal-hernia) or reflux/ [heartburn](https://www.webmd.com/heartburn-gerd/default.htm)). cause live bacterial [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) (such as [typhoid](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/typhoid) [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation)) to not work well. Tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional that you are using doxycycline before having any [immunizations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation)/ [vaccinations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation). Before having surgery, tell your doctor or [dentist](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/oral-health-care-providers) about all the products you use (including [prescription drugs](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), nonprescription drugs, and herbal products). This medication may make you more sensitive to the sun. Limit your time in the sun. Avoid tanning booths and sunlamps. Use [sunscreen](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-366/sunscreen+topical/details) and wear protective clothing when outdoors. Tell your doctor right away if you get sunburned or have [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-faq) [blisters](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/understanding-blisters-basics)/redness. Children younger than 8 years may be more sensitive to the side effects of doxycycline, especially [tooth discoloration](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/features/foods-stain-teeth-feature). [Tooth discoloration](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/healthy-teeth-14/slideshow-foods-stain-teeth) has also occurred in older children and young adults. Discuss the risks and benefits of this medication with the doctor. Tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. You should not become pregnant while using doxycycline. Doxycycline may harm an unborn baby. If you become pregnant, talk to your doctor right away about the risks and benefits of this medication. This medication passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your doctor before breast-feeding. Interactions See also How to Use section. [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your doctor and [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this drug include: [retinoid](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/supplement-guide-vitamin-a) medications taken by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth) (such phenytoin), strontium. This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) may interfere with certain lab tests (such as urine catecholamine levels), possibly causing false test results. Make sure lab personnel and all your doctors know you use this drug. Overdose If someone has overdosed and has serious symptoms such as passing out or [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments), call 911. Otherwise, call a poison control center right away. US residents can call their local poison control center at 1-800-222-1222. Canada residents can call a provincial poison control center. Do not share this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) with others. If this medication is being used to prevent [malaria](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/malaria), it is important to understand that it is still possible to get the disease even if you have used this medication. Avoid being bitten by [mosquitoes](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/illnesses-mosquito-bites) when trying to prevent [malaria](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/malaria-topic-overview). Avoid contact with [mosquitoes](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/ss/slideshow-mosquito-borne-diseases), especially from dusk to dawn, by staying in well-screened areas, wearing protective clothing, and using insect repellent and bed nets. This medication has been prescribed for your current condition only. Do not use it later for another infection unless your doctor tells you to. Lab and/or medical tests (such as [complete blood count](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/complete-blood-count-cbc), [liver](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-liver)/ [kidney](https://www.webmd.com/kidney-stones/picture-of-the-kidneys) function) may be done while you are taking this medication. Keep all medical and lab appointments. Consult your doctor for more details. If you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. If it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose. Take your next dose at the regular time. Do not double the dose to catch up. Store at room temperature away from light and moisture. Different brands of this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) have different storage needs. Check the product package for instructions on how to store your brand, or ask your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Do not store in the bathroom. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Taking outdated [tetracycline](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-5919/tetracycline+oral/details)-related drugs can result in serious illness. Consult your pharmacist or local waste disposal company.
